questions.text: A 53-year-old man has type 2 diabetes. He complains of difficulty walking. On examination, he is unable to evert his right foot. He has intact knee reflexes. There is also sensory loss in the lateral aspect of the foot to a pin prick. Which nerve root is involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests foot eversion weakness with preserved knee reflexes and sensory loss over the lateral foot, pointing toward L5 radiculopathy.
  • Foot eversion is primarily mediated by the peroneal nerve, which receives fibres mainly from L5 and S1 roots.
  • L5 root supplies the lateral dorsum of the foot, sparing the little toe (which is S1).
  • Intact knee reflexes suggest that L3 and L4 (which contribute to the patellar reflex) are not involved.
  • The presence of isolated motor and sensory deficits in the L5 distribution with preserved reflexes helps localise the lesion.

Related Important Points:

  • L5 root lesions often present with weakness of dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot eversion.
  • Sensory loss in L5 involves the lateral leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • S1 root involvement would show loss of ankle jerk and plantar flexion weakness.

Explanation of other options:

L2 (Option A): Controls hip flexion; no role in foot eversion.

L3 (Option B): Involved in knee extension; not relevant to lateral foot sensation or eversion.

S1 (Option D): Supplies the lateral plantar foot and little toe, also involved in ankle reflex, which is not mentioned here.

questions.text: A 59 year old lady presents with back pain that radiates to the knee and down the medial side of the calf towards the medial malleolus. Which nerve root is affected?
questions.solution:
• In contrast, L5 lesion can cause pain radiating through the buttock, down the postero lateral aspect of the thigh, lateral aspect of calf and across the dorsum of the foot.

Reference:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st ed, Ch: 446, Pg: 3498

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents with diplopia. On examination, she has a fixed dilated pupil on the right side. Direct light reflex and accommodation reflex are totally absent. Which one of the Following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A fixed, dilated pupil with loss of both light and accommodation reflexes is a hallmark of complete third cranial nerve palsy with parasympathetic fibre involvement.
  • The oculomotor nerve (CN III) carries parasympathetic fibres to the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle.
  • Compression of these fibres leads to pupil dilation, absent light and accommodation reflexes, and typically ptosis and ophthalmoplegia (not mentioned but not essential for diagnosis).
  • Other choices involve miotic (small) pupils, which do not fit the clinical picture here.

Related Important Points:

  • A pupil-involving 3rd nerve palsy is often due to compressive lesions (e.g., posterior communicating artery aneurysm).
  • In contrast, ischemic (diabetic) 3rd nerve palsy tends to spare the pupil.
  • Early neuroimaging is warranted in painful or pupil-involving 3rd nerve palsies.

Explanation of other options:

Argyll Robertson pupil (Option A): Pupils are small, irregular, and show light-near dissociation (react to accommodation but not light).

Horner's syndrome (Option B): Characterised by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, not mydriasis.

Pilocarpine (Option D): A miotic agent would constrict the pupil, not cause dilation.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man was injured in a road traffic accident. On examination, he is unable to extend his right hand at the wrist. The triceps jerk is diminished, and there is weakness of wrist flexion. A small area over the right middle finger has sensory loss to pain and touch. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical features suggest a C7 radiculopathy, as this root supplies muscles and skin in the affected areas:
  • C7 root innervates:
    • Wrist extensors and flexors
    • Triceps (explaining the diminished triceps reflex
    • Finger extensors
    • Provides sensory supply to the middle finger.
  • Wrist drop, triceps involvement, and middle finger sensory loss collectively point to a C7 root lesion, not an isolated peripheral nerve.

Related Important Points:

  • The triceps jerk is primarily mediated by C7 via the radial nerve.
  • A radial nerve injury would spare wrist flexion and sensory supply to the middle finger.
  • C5 root innervates shoulder abduction and biceps features, not seen here.
  • Ulnar nerve involvement would produce hand muscle weakness, not wrist extensors or triceps issues.

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve (Option A): Would cause wrist drop but not affect wrist flexion or middle finger sensation.

Ulnar nerve (Option B): Involves intrinsic hand muscles, the medial forearm, and the little finger, not the triceps or middle finger.

C5 root (Option C): Supplies shoulder abductors and biceps, with sensory loss in the lateral arm, not the middle finger.

questions.text: A 47-year-old lady has a painful cheek (maxillary area) when chewing. The neurologist diagnoses trigeminal neuralgia. Which is the best medication to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carbamazepine is the first-line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia, an episodic, electric shock-like pain affecting one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve.
  • It stabilises inactivated voltage-gated sodium channels, reducing ectopic discharges in the trigeminal nerve.
  • Effective in >70% of patients, especially during early stages.
  • Alternative drugs: oxcarbazepine, baclofen, or lamotrigine in resistant cases.

Related Important Points:

  • Trigeminal neuralgia typically affects V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) divisions unilaterally.
  • MRI is used to rule out compressive causes like a vascular loop or tumour.
  • If medical treatment fails, surgical options like microvascular decompression or radiofrequency ablation may be considered.

Explanation of other options:

Benztropine (Option A): Anticholinergic used in Parkinson's disease and drug-induced dystonia; no role in trigeminal neuralgia.

Diclofenac (Option B): NSAID for musculoskeletal pain; ineffective in neuralgic pain.

Propranolol (Option C): Used for migraine prophylaxis, not trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man has recently been involved in an accident. On examination, there was increased tone in the right leg; he had right-sided leg weakness and loss of proprioception on the right side of the lower limb. There was also a left-sided loss of sensation to pain in the left leg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This presentation fits the classic picture of Brown-Sequard syndrome, which results from hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • Ipsilateral findings (same side as lesion):
    • Upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spasticity)
    • Proprioception and vibration loss (posterior column)
  • Contralateral findings (opposite side):
    • Loss of pain and temperature (spinothalamic tract, which crosses over early)

In this case:

  • Right leg weakness + proprioception loss (right) = ipsilateral corticospinal and posterior column involvement
  • Pain loss in the left leg = contralateral spinothalamic tract involvement

Related Important Points:

  • Most commonly caused by trauma, tumours, or ischemia involving one-half of the spinal cord.
  • Prognosis is generally good with early diagnosis and supportive therapy.
  • Neurological deficits below the level of the lesion help in localisation.

Explanation of other options:

Myalgic encephalitis (Option A): Chronic fatigue syndrome; no focal neurologic deficits or spinal findings.

Motor neuron disease (Option B): Insidious, progressive; affects upper and lower motor neurons but does not cause sensory loss.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Option D): Rapidly progressive dementia with myoclonus; not related to spinal trauma or focal signs.

questions.text: An 80-year-old lady is admitted complaining of an acute onset of weakness in both legs and low back pain for the previous 4 weeks. She has lost 5 kg of weight recently, and has an Hb of 8.5 g/dl. Her cranial nerves and upper limbs were normal, but she had reduced power in both lower limbs of 3/5. She has a sensory level at T12, and plantar reflexes are upgoing. Rectal tone was normal. Which is the best next investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The best investigation for suspected spinal cord compression is an MRI spine, which provides direct visualisation of the cord, vertebrae, and surrounding soft tissues.
  • The patient shows classic features of compressive myelopathy:
    • Bilateral lower limb weakness (UMN pattern)
    • A sensory level at T12
    • Back pain and recent weight loss are suggestive of malignancy
  • MRI is the gold standard to detect epidural metastasis, abscess, or hematoma compressing the spinal cord.
  • Early identification is vital as spinal cord compression is a neurological emergency requiring prompt decompression or radiotherapy.

Related Important Points:

  • MRI spine is the first-line investigation in any patient with a sensory level and motor weakness.
  • Common cancers causing spinal metastases: lung, breast, prostate, and multiple myeloma.
  • Cord compression often presents with back pain followed by motor/sensory loss, and bladder/bowel dysfunction may follow.
  • Normal rectal tone and no cranial involvement help localise the lesion to the thoracic spinal cord.

Explanation of other options:

Bone scan (Option A): Sensitive for skeletal metastases but not specific for cord compression.

CT scan of the abdomen (Option B): May help detect primary malignancy, but will not evaluate spinal cord involvement.

CT scan of the brain (Option D): Irrelevant here, as the symptoms are spinal, not cerebral.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of severe lower back pain following carpentry work. The pain radiates to his left buttock and thigh. On examination, he was able to straight-leg raise to 45 degrees only on the left side. The sciatic stretch test is positive. He has difficulty plantar flexing his left ankle and has abnormal sensation on the plantar aspect of the foot. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • L5/S1 disc prolapse affects the S1 nerve root, which supplies plantar flexion and sensation to the sole.
  • The presence of sciatic radiation, positive straight leg raise, and plantar sensory loss localises the lesion to the S1 root.
  • Plantar flexion weakness = S1 root
  • Sensation on the plantar foot = S1 dermatome
  • Lumbosacral disc prolapse is most common at L5/S1, followed by L4/L5.

Related Important Points:

  • S1 root also contributes to the ankle jerk reflex, which may be diminished in such cases.
  • The straight leg raise is a sensitive test for lumbar radiculopathy.
  • L4/L5 disc affects dorsiflexion and foot eversion (L5 root).
  • L2-L4 roots control hip and knee movements-not typically involved in sciatica.
  • Cauda equina syndrome involves bladder/bowel incontinence and saddle anaesthesia, not seen here.

Explanation of other options:

Cauda equina syndrome (Option A): Presents with bladder/bowel dysfunction, saddle anaesthesia, and not isolated S1 signs.

L2/L3 disc prolapse (Option B): Affects hip flexors and anterior thigh, not plantar flexion or sciatic distribution.

L4/L5 disc prolapse (Option C): Involves the L5 root, causing dorsiflexion weakness, not plantar.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with double vision that is worse when trying to read a book or walk down stairs. The most likely diagnosis is: A Progressive supranuclear palsy
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle, which functions to depress and intort the eye, especially when it is adducted.
  • In 4th nerve palsy, patients experience vertical diplopia that worsens with:
    • Reading (downward gaze)
    • Walking downstairs
  • Patients often compensate with a head tilt to the opposite side to minimise diplopia.
  • The most common cause is congenital palsy, but it can also result from trauma or microvascular ischemia.

Related Important Points:

  • 3rd nerve palsy typically causes ptosis, pupil dilation, and ophthalmoplegia, not isolated downward gaze diplopia.
  • 6th nerve palsy presents with horizontal diplopia, worse on lateral gaze.
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy affects voluntary vertical gaze but is typically seen in older individuals with other Parkinsonian features.

Explanation of other options:

Progressive supranuclear palsy (Option A): A neurodegenerative disorder affecting voluntary vertical gaze, but it usually occurs in older adults with gait instability and axial rigidity.

3rd nerve palsy (Option C): Causes ptosis, eye down and out, and dilated pupil; not limited to vertical diplopia during reading.

6th nerve palsy (Option D): Affects the lateral rectus, causing horizontal diplopia, not reading-related symptoms.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A 38-year-old alcoholic presents with unsteadiness while walking. On examination, he has increased tone and brisk reflexes in the right leg. Proprioception is abnormal in the right leg. There is a loss of vibration sense in the right leg. There is a decrease in pain and temperature sensation in the left leg. Which one of the following conditions is most likely to be responsible for his weakness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pattern described is classic for Brown-Séquard syndrome, which results from hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • Ipsilateral signs (right leg):
    • UMN signs: increased tone, brisk reflexes (corticospinal tract involvement)
    • Loss of proprioception and vibration (posterior column)
  • Contralateral signs (left leg):
    • Loss of pain and temperature (spinothalamic tract crosses at the spinal level
  • The lesion localises to the right hemisphere, likely around the thoracic level.

Related Important Points:

  • Causes of Brown-Séquard syndrome include trauma, tumours, disc herniation, and inflammatory lesions.
  • Differentiates from subacute combined degeneration, which is bilateral and associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Friedreich's ataxia and syringomyelia are symmetric conditions and would not present with hemicord-type findings.

Explanation of other options:

Syringomyelia (Option A): Causes bilateral loss of pain and temperature with preserved proprioception; usually cervical in location.

Subacute combined degeneration (Option B): Causes bilateral posterior column and corticospinal tract involvement due to B12 deficiency.

Friedrich's ataxia (Option C): A hereditary ataxia with bilateral limb involvement and cerebellar signs, usually early onset.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents with finger weakness, which was diagnosed as an ulnar nerve lesion. Which of the Following muscles is supplied by the ulnar nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The interossei muscles are supplied by the ulnar nerve, which innervates most intrinsic hand muscles except those supplied by the median nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is the primary motor supply to many of the intrinsic muscles of the hand, particularly:
  • Interossei (both dorsal and palmar) - important for finger abduction and adduction
  • Medial two lumbricals (to the ring and little finger)
  • Adductor pollicis
  • Hypothenar muscles: abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi

The median nerve supplies:

  • The lateral two lumbricals
  • Thenar muscles: opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis (superficial head)

Related Important Points:

  • Ulnar nerve palsy causes clawing of the medial two fingers, loss of interosseous function, and grip weakness.
  • Common sites of entrapment: cubital tunnel (elbow) and Guyon's canal (wrist).
  • Sensory loss occurs over the medial 1.5 fingers.

Explanation of other options:

Lateral two lumbricals (Option B): Supplied by the median nerve, not ulnar.

Opponens pollicis (Option C): A thenar muscle, supplied by the median nerve.

Abductor pollicis brevis (Option D): Also a thenar muscle, supplied by the median nerve.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man has slowly progressive weakness of his upper limbs. On examination of the patient, the physical signs are wasting and weakness of the small muscles of the hand, flattening of the muscles of the ulnar border of the forearm. The upper limb reflexes are absent. Pain and temperature sensation are reduced over the upper limbs and upper chest, whereas light touch and proprioception remain intact. Lower limb reflexes are exaggerated, and plantar reflexes are extensor. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a classic presentation of syringomyelia, often secondary to Arnold-Chiari malformation, causing dissociated sensory loss and upper limb LMN signs with lower limb UMN signs.
  • The constellation of findings dissociated sensory loss (pain and temperature impaired with intact touch/proprioception), wasting of hand muscles, areflexic upper limbs, and spastic lower limbs is typical of syringomyelia, which is most commonly associated with Arnold-Chiari type I malformation.
  • Syrinx expands in the central spinal cord, damaging:
    • Anterior horn cells → LMN signs in upper limbs
    • Spinothalamic decussating fibres → selective loss of pain and temperature
    • Lateral corticospinal tracts (when they extend laterally) → UMN signs in lower limbs
  • Arnold-Chiari I involves downward herniation of cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, often leading to syringomyelia in adults.

Related Important Points:

  • Dissociated sensory loss (loss of pain/temp with preserved touch/proprioception) is the hallmark of syringomyelia.
  • Arnold-Chiari II is seen in children and is associated with myelomeningocele and hydrocephalus.
  • MRI spine with brain screening is the investigation of choice.

Explanation of other options:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (Option A): Presents with gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia, not focal limb findings.

Multiple sclerosis (Option B): Typically presents with multifocal CNS involvement, often optic neuritis, sensory disturbances, but not dissociated sensory loss.

Severe kyphoscoliosis (Option D): Can cause cord compression, but would not typically produce the selective sensory findings seen here.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady is found to have a left-sided posterior communicating artery aneurysm on cerebral angiography. Which of the following would you expect to find?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Posterior communicating artery aneurysms commonly compress the third cranial nerve, leading to pupillary involvement and ophthalmoplegia.
    Aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery (PCOM) are the most common cause of a compressive third nerve palsy.
  • The oculomotor nerve (CN III) passes near the PCOM and is highly susceptible to compression by aneurysms at this site.
  • Parasympathetic fibres, which control pupillary constriction, lie superficially on the nerve and are first to be affected, leading to:
    • Dilated pupil (mydriasis)
    • Ptosis (levator palpebrae paralysis)
    • "Down and out" eye (due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and the superior oblique)
  • This is in contrast to ischemic 3rd nerve palsy (e.g., from diabetes), which spares the pupil.

Related Important Points:

  • Painful third nerve palsy with pupillary involvement is considered an aneurysmal 3rd nerve palsy until proven otherwise.
  • Emergency neuroimaging (CTA/MRA or angiography) is required.
  • PCOM aneurysm is a neurosurgical emergency due to the risk of rupture and subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Explanation of other options:

Facial nerve palsy (Option A): Caused by lesions affecting CN VII, not related to PCOM aneurysms.

Left pupillary constriction (Option B): Aneurysm causes dilation, not constriction, due to parasympathetic fibre damage.

Downgaze palsy (Option C): Seen in Parinaud syndrome due to midbrain lesions, not CN III compression.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing examination of the eye. The patient has a direct response to light shone in the right eye, but no consensual response. Light shone in the left eye elicits a consensual response, but not a direct response. During pursuit eye movements, the left eye is fixed in an inferior and lateral position. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A left oculomotor nerve palsy causes a dilated, nonreactive left pupil and "down and out" eye, with preserved afferent function.
  • This pattern is consistent with a left third nerve (oculomotor) palsy, which affects:
    • Efferent limb of the pupillary light reflex (parasympathetics to the sphincter pupillae)
    • Extraocular muscles: result in the eye fixed in the down and out position (unopposed action of lateral rectus and superior oblique)
    • Levator palpebrae: causes ptosis (not mentioned here but commonly present)

Light reflex interpretation:

  • Right eye direct present + no left consensual → Left efferent defect
  • Left eye no direct + right consensual present → Left afferent is intact, confirms left efferent defect

Related Important Points:

  • The optic nerve (CN II) mediates the afferent limb of the light reflex.
  • The oculomotor nerve (CN III) controls the efferent limb to the pupil and most extraocular muscles.
  • A fixed dilated pupil with eye deviated down and out is classic for third nerve palsy.
  • Third nerve lesions can be compressive (aneurysm) or ischemic (diabetes).

Explanation of other options:

Right trochlear nerve (Option A): Affects the superior oblique, may cause vertical diplopia but not pupillary or "down and out" findings.

Left optic nerve (Option B): Would impair the afferent limb, affecting both direct and consensual response to light in the left eye, not the pattern seen here.

Right abducens nerve (Option D): Affects lateral rectus, causes horizontal diplopia, not pupil or downward eye deviation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman has had neck pains and occipital headaches for 2 years. She is referred to the neurology outpatients for assessment. Investigations showed a normal CT of the brain. Cervical X-ray showed degenerative changes of narrowed disc spaces and loss of cervical lordosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Degenerative disc changes with suboccipital headache and neck pain point to cervical spondylosis, not intracranial pathology.
  • Cervical spondylosis is the most common cause of chronic neck pain in the elderly and may present with:
    • Neck and shoulder pain
    • Suboccipital (occipital) headaches
    • Cervical radiculopathy or myelopathy
    • Stiffness and reduced cervical range of motion

Radiological findings in cervical spondylosis include:

  • Disc space narrowing
  • Loss of cervical lordosis
  • Osteophyte formation
  • Facet joint osteoarthritis
  • Uncovertebral joint hypertrophy

A normal CT brain helps exclude central causes like haemorrhage or stroke.

Related Important Points:

  • Occipital headaches in elderly patients should raise suspicion for cervical spondylosis if associated with neck stiffness or radiculopathy.
  • Temporal arteritis typically presents with temporal tenderness, jaw claudication, and elevated ESR, not neck pain.
  • Occipital neuralgia causes sharp, shooting pain over the occipital nerve distribution, not associated with X-ray changes.

Explanation of other options:

Cerebellar haemorrhage (Option A): Would present acutely with ataxia, vertigo, vomiting, and an abnormal CT brain.

Temporal arteritis (Option B): Presents with temporal headache, scalp tenderness, and visual symptoms; ESR is elevated.

Occipital neuralgia (Option C): Involves paroxysmal occipital pain without radiographic spinal changes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady complains of the gradual onset of blurred vision in her left eye. Examination reveals a left-sided relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy reveals left-sided optic atrophy. Visual fields show a left-sided central scotoma and an upper quadrantic visual field defect in the right eye. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A lesion at the junction of the left optic nerve and chiasma causes ipsilateral central scotoma and contralateral superior quadrantanopia due to partial involvement of decussating nasal fibres.
  • The findings described are classical for a lesion at the anterior portion of the optic chiasm (junction of optic nerve and chiasm), often called a junctional scotoma.
  • Left optic nerve involvement → central scotoma, optic atrophy, RAPD (Marcus Gunn pupil) on the left side.
  • Involvement of decussating nasal fibres from the right eye (in the inferior chiasm) → right superior quadrantanopia.
  • This pattern occurs because the inferonasal fibres of the right retina (which view the upper temporal field) cross at the anterior chiasma.

Related Important Points:

  • Lesions here are commonly due to compressive causes: suprasellar tumours, craniopharyngiomas, pituitary macroadenomas, or meningiomas.
  • Optic chiasma lesions classically produce bitemporal hemianopia, but anterior chiasmal involvement causes asymmetric field defects.
  • Optic nerve lesions alone do not cause contralateral field defects.

Explanation of other options:

Left optic nerve (Option A): Would explain central scotoma and optic atrophy, but not the contralateral field defect.

Sphenoid wing (Option C): Usually compresses the optic nerve or chiasm from the side, but not a classic location for this visual field pattern.

Left occipital area (Option D): Would cause contralateral homonymous hemianopia or quadrantanopia, not a monocular scotoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with frequent headaches and loss of libido. He was found to have hypopituitarism on investigation. The CT scan shows a pituitary tumour with suprasellar extension. Which of the Following structures is likely to be compressed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The optic chiasma is located just superior to the pituitary gland. As a pituitary macroadenoma grows upward (suprasellar extension), it compresses the central part of the optic chiasma, where the nasal fibres from both retinas cross.
  • This leads to bitemporal hemianopia, the classic visual field defect in pituitary macroadenomas.
  • The patient also shows hypopituitarism, suggesting functional compromise of anterior pituitary hormones (e.g., reduced libido from low LH/FSH/testosterone).

Related Important Points:

  • Pituitary macroadenomas (>10 mm) commonly cause:
    • Headache due to local pressure
    • Visual field loss due to optic chiasma compression
    • Endocrinopathies: hypo- or hypersecretion of pituitary hormones
  • MRI is more sensitive than CT for pituitary imaging.
  • Compression of the lateral chiasm may affect one eye more than the other in asymmetric cases.

Explanation of other options:

Abducens nerve (Option A): Runs in the cavernous sinus; more likely affected in lateral tumour extension, not suprasellar.

Olfactory bulb (Option B): Located in the anterior cranial fossa; not near the pituitary gland.

Trochlear nerve (Option C): Courses laterally and dorsally around the midbrain, not affected by suprasellar masses.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman has sensory loss and wasting of the small hand muscles. In one examination, she also has a right-sided Horner's syndrome. Her arms demonstrate thickening of the subcutaneous tissues. There is also evidence of Charcot's joints on the wrists. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Syringomyelia is the only condition listed that presents with dissociated sensory loss, small hand muscle wasting, Horner's syndrome, and Charcot's joints.
  • Syringomyelia is a chronic disorder characterised by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) within the central spinal cord, most commonly in the cervical region.
  • Destruction of anterior horn cells → LMN signs (e.g., hand muscle wasting)
  • Damage to decussating spinothalamic fibres → loss of pain and temperature with preserved proprioception (dissociated sensory loss)
  • Involvement of the ciliospinal centre (T1) → Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis)
  • Chronic joint degeneration and neuropathy → Charcot's joints
  • Thickening of skin and subcutaneous tissues due to autonomic dysfunction

Related Important Points:

  • Common causes: Chiari I malformation, trauma, tumours, and arachnoiditis.
  • Classically affects young to middle-aged adults, with slow progression.
  • MRI spine is the investigation of choice.

Explanation of other options:

Hereditary spinocerebellar ataxia (Option A): Causes cerebellar signs, ataxia, and dysarthria; not associated with Horner's syndrome or Charcot joints.

Hereditary spastic paraparesis (Option B): Produces bilateral lower limb spasticity, not upper limb wasting or dissociated sensory loss.

Motor neuron disease (Option C): Affects both upper and lower motor neurons, but does not involve sensory deficits or Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: A 47-year-old teacher develops a sided facial weakness in association with hearing loss and pain in the right ear. On examination, there is a vesicular rash over the right ear, and right lower motor neuron 7th nerve palsy. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This clinical presentation is classic for Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which is caused by reactivation of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (CN VII).
  • Key features include:
    • LMN facial palsy (complete unilateral weakness of all facial muscles)
    • Pain in the ear
    • Vesicular eruption on the pinna or external auditory canal
    • Ipsilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, or vertigo (due to CN VIII involvement)
  • This distinguishes it from Bell's palsy, which has no rash or auditory symptoms.

Related Important Points:

  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome may also involve cranial nerves V and VIII, causing vertigo or sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Antiviral therapy (e.g., acyclovir) + corticosteroids is typically initiated early.
  • Prognosis is poorer than Bell's palsy, especially if treatment is delayed.

Explanation of other options:

Lyme disease (Option A): Can cause bilateral facial palsy but lacks vesicular rash and is associated with tick exposure.

Diabetes (Option C): Can lead to cranial mononeuropathy (like Bell's palsy), but without rash or auditory involvement.

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option D): Affects medium-sized arteries; may cause mononeuritis multiplex but not vesicular rash or isolated facial palsy.

questions.text: A 61-year-old patient has diplopia looking to the left. When the left eye is covered, the outer image disappears. Which nerve is involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a classic presentation of left abducens (CN VI) nerve palsy, which supplies the lateral rectus muscle responsible for abduction of the eye.
  • In abducens palsy:
    • The affected eye cannot abduct → leading to horizontal diplopia, worse on gaze toward the affected side.
    • Covering the affected eye (left) eliminates the false (outer) image, confirming it is the source of diplopia.
  • Diplopia improves when the normal eye is covered, as the paretic eye is no longer required to fixate.

Related Important Points:

  • Abducens nerve palsy is the most common ocular motor palsy and may be caused by:
    • Microvascular ischemia (e.g., diabetes, hypertension)
    • Raised intracranial pressure
    • Brainstem stroke, tumour, or trauma
  • Abducens palsy presents with esotropia (inward deviation) of the affected eye at rest.

Explanation of other options:

Right abducens (Option B): Would affect right gaze, not left.

Left trochlear (Option C): Affects the superior oblique, causing vertical diplopia, especially on downward gaze.

Right trochlear (Option D): Would cause vertical diplopia, not horizontal diplopia on left gaze.

choices.text: Subacute combined generation of the cord

questions.text: A 71-year-old man has a 2-month history of progressive weakness in his legs. He has a weakness in the hip and knee distribution. Knee and ankle reflexes are brisk. Plantar are upgoing bilaterally. He has sensory loss from his legs upwards towards the T5 level. Which one of the Following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of progressive spastic paraparesis with a clear sensory level (T5) is suggestive of compressive myelopathy, and thoracic meningioma is a common intradural extramedullary spinal tumour that can present in this manner.
  • Meningiomas in the thoracic region may compress the spinal cord, leading to:
    • Bilateral leg weakness (UMN type)
    • Hyperreflexia (brisk reflexes)
    • Upgoing plantar reflexes (Babinski sign)
    • A defined sensory level, indicating a lesion within the spinal cord

Related Important Points:

  • A sensory level is a hallmark of spinal cord pathology, especially compressive lesions.
  • Subacute combined degeneration affects the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts but usually has absent ankle reflexes due to coexisting peripheral neuropathy.
  • Friedreich's ataxia is inherited and presents earlier with ataxia, loss of position sense, and mixed UMN/LMN signs, often with cardiomyopathy.
  • Hereditary spastic paraparesis involves slow, progressive spasticity and weakness in the lower limbs but does not produce a sensory level.

Explanation of other options:

Subacute combined degeneration (Option A): Associated with B12 deficiency, presents with posterior column signs and absent ankle jerks.

Friedreich's ataxia (Option B): Presents in young individuals with ataxia and cardiac features, not elderly with sensory level.

Hereditary spastic paraparesis (Option D): Has no sensory level and progresses more slowly without defined dermatome involvement

questions.text: Which of the following will not be affected by a lesion of the facial nerve in the internal auditory meatus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sweating is mediated by sympathetic fibres, not the facial nerve, hence spared in facial nerve lesions, even at the internal auditory meatus.
  • A lesion of the facial nerve within the internal auditory meatus affects the nerve before it exits the stylomastoid foramen, and thus disrupts all facial nerve branches, both motor and parasympathetic.

Affected functions at this level include:

  • Blinking (orbicularis oculi): due to motor branch involvement(Option A)
  • Hearing (hyperacusis): due to loss of stapedius muscle innervation (Option B)
  • Lacrimation: due to damage to the greater petrosal nerve (Option C)
  • Taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and salivation: due to chorda tympani involvement

However, sweating over the cheek is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system, which travels via the superior cervical ganglion, and is not carried by the facial nerve.

Related Important Points:

  • The facial nerve in the internal auditory meatus lies alongside the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII); thus, hearing may be affected.
  • Schirmer's test evaluates lacrimal gland function in facial nerve palsy.
  • Stapedius reflex testing reveals hyperacusis in proximal facial nerve lesions.
  • Blinking is mediated by the efferent limb of the corneal reflex through the facial nerve (motor), while the afferent limb is trigeminal (V1).

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with an insidious onset of binocular horizontal diplopia and left-sided facial pain. On examination, he has a left abducens nerve palsy and numbness over the maxillary division of the left trigeminal nerve. Of the following, which is the most likely anatomical site of his neurological lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Simultaneous involvement of CN VI and the maxillary division (V2) of CN V localises the lesion to the apex of the petrous bone, consistent with Gradenigo syndrome.
  • The petrous apex of the temporal bone houses critical neurovascular structures, including:
  • The abducens nerve (CN VI) as it traverses Dorello's canal, and
  • The trigeminal ganglion, particularly its maxillary (V2) division

A lesion here, whether due to osteitis (Gradenigo syndrome), meningioma, or nasopharyngeal carcinoma, can cause:

  • Horizontal diplopia (from CN VI palsy → impaired lateral rectus),
  • Facial pain or numbness in the V2 dermatome,
  • It may also be associated with deep otitis media, petrositis, or skull base tumours.

This pattern defines Gradenigo syndrome, a rare but classic presentation of petrous apex pathology.

Related Important Points:

  • Gradenigo syndrome triad:
    • CN VI palsy
    • CN V2 sensory loss
    • Otitis media or petrositis (historically common in the pre-antibiotic era)
  • Differentiation:
    • Cavernous sinus syndrome involves III, IV, V1, V2, and VI with proptosis or chemosis.
    • The cerebellopontine angle affects CN V, VII, VIII, not CN VI and CN V2.
    • Midbrain lesions affect vertical gaze, CN III, and contralateral motor tracts, not this combination.

Explanation of other options:

Cavernous sinus (Option A): Involves multiple cranial nerves, including CN III, IV, V1, V2, and VI, but typically causes proptosis, chemosis, or orbital congestion, not isolated V2 + VI.

Cerebellopontine angle (Option B): Affects CN V, VII, VIII, often with hearing loss, facial palsy, or ataxia, not consistent here.

Midbrain (Option C): Causes CN III palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and does not involve CN VI and V2 simultaneously.

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presents to his family doctor with a two-week history of numbness and a burning sensation on the lateral aspect of the left upper thigh. Examination reveals sensory loss over the anterolateral thigh. Which one of the following nerves is most likely to be involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isolated sensory loss in the anterolateral thigh strongly indicates entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, a condition known as meralgia paresthetica.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is a pure sensory branch of the lumbar plexus, arising from L2-L3, which passes under the inguinal ligament near the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS).
  • Compression or entrapment at this point (commonly due to tight belts, obesity, or pregnancy) leads to:
    • Burning/tingling paresthesia
    • Hypoesthesia or anaesthesia in the anterolateral thigh
  • There is no motor involvement, helping distinguish it from femoral or root lesions.

Related Important Points:

  • Meralgia paresthetica is a common compressive mononeuropathy.
  • It may be aggravated by prolonged standing, tight clothing, or abdominal obesity.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Involvement causes both motor (quadriceps) and sensory loss in the anterior thigh, not isolated lateral thigh sensory symptoms.

L2 nerve root (Option B): Would produce more diffuse pain radiating to the groin or anterior thigh, not restricted lateral thigh sensory symptoms.

L3 nerve root (Option C): Typically affects the anterior/medial thigh with motor involvement, not the isolated anterolateral sensory loss seen here.

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the thigh
Weakness of abduction of the hip
Weakness of adduction at the hip

questions.text: A 27-year-old male is admitted following an altercation in which he was stabbed in the thigh by a bottle. Which of the following features suggests injury to the femoral nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps femoris muscle, responsible for knee extension and the knee jerk reflex. Injury leads to:
  • Weakness of knee extension
  • Loss of knee (patellar) reflex
  • Sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg (via the saphenous branch)
  • The femoral nerve arises from L2-L4 roots and courses through the femoral triangle in the upper thigh, making it vulnerable to penetrating trauma.

Related Important Points:

  • Abduction of the hip is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.
  • Adduction of the hip is performed by the obturator nerve.
  • Sensation over the lateral thigh is carried by the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, not the femoral nerve.
  • The femoral nerve injury is classically tested via the knee jerk reflex.

Explanation of other options:

Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the thigh (Option B): Indicates lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh injury (meralgia paresthetica), not femoral nerve.

Weakness of abduction of the hip (Option C): Caused by superior gluteal nerve injury (not femoral).

Weakness of adduction at the hip (Option D): Caused by obturator nerve involvement, not femoral.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with new double vision. On examination, she experiences horizontal diplopia on looking to her far right. Covering her left eye only obscures the innermost image. Covering her right eye only obscures the outermost image. In the neutral position, her right eye is deviated medially. She has no problem looking to the far left. Her neurological examination is otherwise normal. What is the most likely problem?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The right abducens (VIth) nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for abduction of the right eye:
  • A lesion results in the inability to abduct the affected eye → medial deviation at rest (unopposed medial rectus).
  • Horizontal diplopia worsens on right gaze.
  • The cover test helps identify the affected eye:
    • Covering the right (affected) eye makes the outer image (false image from misaligned eye) disappear.
    • Covering the left (normal) eye leaves only the inner image (true image from the aligned eye).

Related Important Points:

  • Abducens nerve palsy is commonly caused by raised intracranial pressure due to its long intracranial course.
  • It is considered a false localising sign in cases of raised ICP.
  • Horizontal diplopia, especially in lateral gaze, strongly suggests a VI nerve lesion.
  • Always investigate the underlying causes of VI nerve palsy (e.g., tumours, trauma, diabetes, ICP elevation).

Explanation of other options:

Concomitant right esotropia (Option A): A developmental squint present in all directions; not typically associated with diplopia in adults or gaze-specific findings.

Left-sided IVth nerve palsy (Option B): Involves the superior oblique muscle, causing vertical diplopia, typically worse on downward gaze.

Left-sided VIth nerve palsy (Option C): Would cause horizontal diplopia on left gaze, not right; the eye would deviate medially on the left.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient with a long history of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis develops double vision. On examination of his eye movements, abduction of either eye elicits nystagmus in that eye. Adduction is impaired in both eyes. On MRI scanning, where will a new white matter lesion probably be evident?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which coordinates horizontal eye movements between the nuclei of cranial nerves III and VI.
  • Bilateral impairment of adduction with abducting nystagmus is classic for bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia.
  • The MLF lesion disrupts conjugate gaze by disconnecting the contralateral abducens nucleus from the ipsilateral oculomotor nucleus.
  • Common causes include multiple sclerosis (especially bilateral lesions), brainstem infarcts, and, less commonly, Wernicke's encephalopathy or gliomas.

Related Important Points:

  • The MLF is a paired tract located near the midline in the dorsal pons and midbrain.
  • In unilateral INO, only one eye fails to adduct with horizontal gaze.
  • Convergence is preserved in most cases, distinguishing it from oculomotor palsy.
  • MRI typically shows high signal lesions on T2-weighted or FLAIR sequences in MLF.

Explanation of other options:

Cerebellum (Option A): Lesions here cause ataxia, dysmetria, and gaze-evoked nystagmus, not INO.

Cingulate gyrus (Option B): Part of the limbic system; not involved in ocular movement pathways.

Optic chiasma (Option D): Lesions cause visual field defects (e.g., bitemporal hemianopia), not gaze palsy or nystagmus.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man has drunk six units of alcohol a day for most of his adult life. He has had worsening symptoms of difficulty walking, headaches and urinary incontinence for the past ten months. Of the following, which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Syringomyelia causes a central cavitation (syrinx) in the spinal cord, typically presenting with sensory dissociation and progressive motor and autonomic dysfunctions.
  • The triad of gait disturbance, headache, and urinary symptoms suggests cord involvement rather than cortical (encephalopathy) or meningeal (syphilis) causes.
  • Syringomyelia typically affects the cervical or upper thoracic cord, with signs depending on the level and extent.
  • It causes segmental loss of pain and temperature (spinothalamic tract) with sparing of fine touch and proprioception.
  • Lower motor neuron signs (e.g., muscle wasting in hands) may occur early, followed by upper motor neuron signs as the syrinx expands.
  • Bladder dysfunction and even Horner's syndrome can occur with further extension.

Related Important Points:

  • Common cause: Chiari I malformation; others include trauma, tumours, or arachnoiditis.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice; lumbar puncture is contraindicated due to herniation risk.
  • Differentiated from Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus, which includes memory loss and gait apraxia.
  • Treatment involves neurosurgical decompression in selected cases.

Explanation of other options:

Encephalopathy (Option A): Would cause altered sensorium or drowsiness, not present here.

Meningovascular syphilis (Option B): Rare; usually presents with meningitis, stroke-like features or focal deficits, not this chronic triad.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (Option C): Classically presents with gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia; no cognitive issues here.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents with acute back pain followed by weakness of dorsiflexion of her left foot. Where would you expect the associated sensory loss?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Loss of dorsiflexion of the foot with sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot strongly suggests an L5 radiculopathy.
  • The L5 nerve root innervates the tibialis anterior (dorsiflexor) and sensory fibres to the dorsum of the foot and big toe.
  • It is commonly affected by degenerative disc disease or herniated nucleus pulposus, compressing the L5 root.
  • The pattern of motor weakness (foot drop) and sensory deficit (dorsum of foot) helps distinguish it from peroneal neuropathy, which often spares inversion.

Related Important Points:

  • L5 radiculopathy affects dorsiflexors, toe extensors, and hip abductors.
  • Sensory loss involves the dorsum of the foot, the great toe, and the lateral shin.
  • It may mimic peroneal neuropathy, but L5 radiculopathy also weakens ankle inverters, unlike isolated peroneal nerve injury.
  • MRI and electrodiagnostic studies (EDx) help in localisation.
  • Common causes: Herniated discs, spinal stenosis, and diabetic radiculopathy.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior thigh (Option A): Sensory territory of the femoral nerve and L2-L3 roots, not involved in L5 radiculopathy.

Perineum (Option C): Supplied by sacral roots (S2-S4), typically affected in cauda equina syndrome.

Posterior calf (Option D): Supplied by S1 nerve root, not typical of L5 pathology.

choices.text: Inability to pinch paper between his thumb and index finger
Loss of sensation over the lateral three and a half fingers
Wasting of the second lumbrical muscle

questions.text: A 2-year-old man presents to the Emergency department after punching a window. He has lacerated the medial aspect of his wrist, damaging the ulnar nerve. What is he at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Injury to the ulnar nerve at the wrist leads to paralysis of most intrinsic hand muscles, especially the interossei and medial two lumbricals, resulting in an ulnar claw hand.
  • Ulnar nerve injury at the wrist spares forearm muscles but affects hand intrinsics, leading to:
    • Hyperextension at the MCP joints
    • Flexion at IP joints (due to unopposed long flexors and extensors)
  • This results in a characteristic clawing of the 4th and 5th digits.
  • Sensory loss is restricted to the medial 1½ fingers (little finger and half of the ring finger).
  • Hypothenar wasting and weakness in fine motor tasks like finger abduction/adduction may also be seen.

Related Important Points:

  • Claw hand is more prominent when the ulnar nerve is damaged at the wrist compared to the elbow (due to intact FDP innervation from above).
  • The ulnar nerve also supplies the adductor pollicis, which may be tested using Froment's sign (compensatory flexion of the thumb IP joint using FPL from the median nerve).
  • Common causes: Trauma, deep lacerations at the wrist, Guyon's canal syndrome, prolonged compression (e.g., cyclists).

Explanation of other options:

Inability to pinch paper between thumb and index finger (Option B): Seen in anterior interosseous nerve injury, a branch of the median nerve.

Loss of sensation over the lateral three and a half fingers (Option C): Indicates median nerve injury, not ulnar.

Wasting of the second lumbrical muscle (Option D): The 2nd lumbrical is supplied by the median nerve, not the ulnar.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with severe back pain and urinary retention with overflow. She says that her lower back has been aching for the past six weeks, but the pain has become significantly worse over the past 48 hours. There is a medical history of hypertension, but nothing else of note. Her BP is 142/82 mmHg, pulse is 73/min, regular. She is unable to get off the couch due to distal lower limb weakness. Tone is increased bilaterally, and her reflexes are increased. As you chat to her, you notice fasciculation. There is perianal loss of sensation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs in the lower limbs, combined with perianal sensory loss and urinary retention, points toward Conus Medullaris Syndrome.
  • The conus medullaris is the terminal segment of the spinal cord and contains both UMN tracts and LMN cell bodies.
  • UMN signs: increased tone and hyperreflexia.
  • LMN signs: fasciculations and distal lower limb weakness.
  • Perianal sensory loss and autonomic dysfunction (bladder involvement) are classic.
  • The symptom progression over weeks with acute worsening in the last 48 hours is also characteristic.

Related Important Points:

  • Conus Medullaris Syndrome often presents with:
    • Early bladder and bowel dysfunction
    • Symmetrical motor weakness (mostly distal)
    • Perianal and saddle anaesthesia
    • Mixed UMN and LMN signs
  • Cauda Equina Syndrome is predominantly LMN and presents with flaccid paralysis, asymmetric sensory loss, and later-onset bladder involvement.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice to differentiate between the two.
  • Causes include tumours, trauma, herniated disc, or infarction.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior spinal artery aneurysm (Option A): Rare, and would present with sudden catastrophic symptoms; not a progressive picture over weeks.

Anterior spinal artery thrombosis (Option B): Causes acute onset of paraplegia with preserved dorsal column function; not matching this slow-progressive clinical course.

Cauda equina syndrome (Option C): Pure LMN signs with flaccid tone and decreased reflexes, which are absent here.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with blurred vision in his right eye. Examination reveals visual acuity in the right eye of 6/18 and in the left eye of 6/6. Visual fields to confrontation reveal a right temporal visual field defect and partial loss of the superior part of the temporal field of the left eye. Where is the most likely position of the lesion responsible for this defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A lesion involving the optic chiasma, with possible extension into the right optic nerve, best explains the patient's findings:
  • Right eye: Reduced visual acuity and temporal field loss → implies optic nerve involvement.
  • Left eye: Partial superior temporal field loss → implies partial chiasmal involvement.
  • Chiasmal lesions typically produce bitemporal hemianopia due to involvement of decussating nasal retinal fibres.
  • When there is asymmetry (right more affected), it suggests a lesion at the junction of the chiasma and right optic nerve (junctional scotoma).

Related Important Points:

  • The optic chiasma receives nasal fibres from both eyes that cross to the contralateral side → lesions here cause bitemporal field defects.
  • A lesion involving the junction of the optic nerve and chiasma (as in this case) can also cause decreased acuity in one eye and field loss in the other.
  • Common causes: pituitary macroadenoma, craniopharyngioma, meningioma.
  • MRI brain with pituitary protocol is the investigation of choice.

Explanation of other options:

Occipital lobe (Option A): Causes congruous homonymous hemianopia; visual acuity is usually preserved.

Optic nerve (Option C): Alone would cause unilateral vision loss, not bilateral field defects.

Optic tract (Option D): Causes incongruous homonymous hemianopia, not a bitemporal pattern.

questions.text: A 4-year-old civil servant attends the clinic, stating that she has difficulty swallowing. She gives a two-month history of difficulty with solids, which has progressed to difficulty tolerating liquids in the previous two weeks. She has noticed some weakness in her right arm, which has affected her ability to lift certain objects like the kettle. Previously, she has enjoyed good health with no hearing loss or facial weakness. She describes no visual symptoms. On examination, she has an absent gag reflex on the right, with reduced palatal movements. There is weakness in rotating the head to the left, with flattening and weakness of elevation of the right shoulder. Eye movements, visual acuity, hearing and tongue movements are all normal. Where is the likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of palatal weakness, dysphagia, and right-sided sternocleidomastoid and trapezius weakness points to involvement of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI on the right side:
  • Glossopharyngeal (IX): Absent gag reflex
  • Vagus (X): Palatal weakness and dysphagia
  • Accessory (XI): Weakness of head rotation (contralateral) and shoulder elevation (ipsilateral)
  • These three nerves exit the skull through the jugular foramen, making it the likely lesion site.

Related Important Points:

  • Lesions at the jugular foramen classically cause Vernet's syndrome (IX, X, XI palsy).
  • The absence of hearing loss or facial palsy helps rule out a cerebello-pontine angle tumour (e.g., acoustic neuroma).
  • Lesions at the cerebello-pontine angle typically involve CN VIII and CN VII.
  • If tongue weakness (XII) were present, the lesion would be extracranial beyond the foramen.

Explanation of other options:

Left cerebello-pontine angle (Option A): Would involve left CN VII and VIII, not consistent with the findings.

Left jugular foramen (Option B): Incorrect side; all symptoms are right-sided.

Right cerebello-pontine angle (Option C): CN VII and VIII would be affected, but they are normal here.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with drooping of the left side of her face and an inability to close her left eye. She had a viral illness in the preceding week. There is no past medical history. On examination, there is a left VIIth nerve palsy. The remaining cranial nerves are normal. Power, tone and reflexes are normal in the limbs. What is the best course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with acute unilateral lower motor neuron facial palsy, consistent with Bell's palsy, likely post-viral in origin:
  • The condition typically follows a viral prodrome (often HSV).
  • Current evidence supports a short course of oral corticosteroids, especially if started early (within 72 hours).
  • Some guidelines also recommend oral antivirals (valacyclovir or acyclovir) in addition to steroids, though the benefit from antivirals alone is unclear.
  • The 2007 NEJM study showed that prednisolone improved facial nerve recovery, while acyclovir alone did not, but combination therapy is still widely practised.

Related Important Points:

  • Facial nerve (CN VII) LMN palsy affects both upper and lower parts of the face on the same side.
  • UMN lesions spare the upper face due to bilateral cortical innervation.
  • Always rule out GBS (check limb reflexes), CNS lesions, or stroke.
  • Eye care (e.g., artificial tears, eye patch) is essential due to the inability to close eyelids fully.

Explanation of other options:

Intravenous immunoglobulin (Option A): Used in Guillain-Barré syndrome, not Bell's palsy.

No treatment (Option B): Recovery may occur spontaneously, but early steroid therapy improves outcomes.

Oral prednisolone alone (Option C): Effective, but many guidelines favour adding valacyclovir due to possible viral aetiology.

questions.text: A 2-year-old man suffers a deep laceration to the forearm, resulting in transection of the median nerve. Following this injury, the nerve will undergo which of the following pathological processes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classic pathological process that occurs distal to a severed axon in both the central and peripheral nervous systems is Wallerian degeneration:
  • Begins within 24-36 hours of axonal injury.
  • Involves the breakdown of the axon and its myelin sheath distal to the site of injury.
  • Macrophages clean up debris, and Schwann cells proliferate to support potential axonal regrowth (in PNS).
  • Central nervous system (CNS) regeneration is limited due to a lack of a supportive glial environment.

Related Important Points:

  • Wallerian degeneration is essential for peripheral nerve regeneration and is followed by axon sprouting in some cases.
  • CNS injury shows similar degeneration but fails to regenerate
  • Segmental demyelination without axonal loss can occur in conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • Different types of necrosis (coagulative, fibrinoid) occur in other pathologies, not nerve transection.

Explanation of other options:

Chronic inflammation (Option A): Seen in autoimmune or persistent infections, not the main response to nerve transection.

Coagulative necrosis (Option B): Common in ischemic tissue like the heart and kidney, not nerves.

Fibrinoid necrosis (Option C): Occurs in immune-mediated vascular diseases (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa).

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presented with pain radiating from the left side of her neck down the lateral arm and forearm. She reports difficulty lifting her arm and weakness in her shoulder. She has a known history of rheumatoid arthritis on steroids and penicillamine. Examination reveals deltoid wasting with fasciculations, weakness of shoulder abduction, elbow flexion, and supination. Tone is reduced at the elbow and wrist, biceps reflex is present only on reinforcement, supinator jerk is inverted, and triceps reflex is brisk. There is sensory loss over the lateral arm and forearm. The right arm is normal. In the lower limbs, tone is increased, reflexes are brisk, and plantar responses are extensor bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture is most consistent with cervical myelopathy, particularly due to rheumatoid arthritis-related cervical spine involvement:
  • Weakness and wasting of the deltoid, biceps, and supinator suggest involvement at the C5-C6
  • Inverted supinator reflex is a hallmark of C5/C6 spinal cord involvement.
  • Hypertonia and hyperreflexia in both legs with extensor plantar responses confirm long tract (UMN) signs, suggesting spinal cord compression.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a known cause of atlantoaxial subluxation or cervical spine instability, which can compress the spinal cord.

Related Important Points:

  • Cervical myelopathy causes mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs depending on level and severity.
  • In C5/C6 involvement, biceps and supinator reflexes may be diminished while triceps are spared or brisk.
  • Patients may have "cape-like" sensory loss and bladder involvement in advanced stages.
  • A prompt MRI cervical spine is required for diagnosis and surgical planning.

Explanation of other options:

Circumflex neuropathy (Option B): Involves the deltoid but does not explain leg UMN signs or biceps/supinator weakness.

Inclusion body myositis (Option C): Typically presents with painless bilateral distal weakness, not UMN signs or reflex changes.

Motor neurone disease (Option D): Involves UMN + LMN signs without sensory symptoms, which are present here.
